subject: Re: [junit] gui testing
msgSnippet: ... We may be talking at cross purposes and not understanding each other. Let s get specific. Imagine a Dialog with several test fields, labels, and buttons -
messageBody:
On 6/11/02 8:06 AM, "Timothy Wall" <twall@...> wrote:

> I dunno. I've been developing GUIs on a number of platforms for years,
> and I thought I was only doing very basic tool-oriented tasks, but I've
> never done a gui that reduces to a single component with a single
> message. Maybe I just don't establish the proper concepts in the gui,
> but I invariably have several things interacting.

We may be talking at cross purposes and not understanding each other. Let's
get specific. Imagine a Dialog with several test fields, labels, and buttons
- just to be specific. There are several components that can generate events
to the Mediator/Presenter/Fa√ßade or whatever we want to call it. The
Presenter sends several messages to the Dialog through an interface.


>
> Yes, the right message gets sent to the Dialog, but the Dialog still
> doesn't show up. Now what?

There's an API call to make it appear - I've been in C++/MFC land the last
few weeks so I forget what it is - setVisible(true)??? or something like
that.

So if the Presenter sends a show() message to the Dialog, and show() is
implemented with a setVisible(true), and you say it doesn't appear, what are
you going to do about it? I maintain that a unit test of the Dialog doesn't
give any better feedback than just looking at the thing - or in this case,
looking for the thing ;-)


> In my experience, the design space between
> two components is where I find the most bugs; it's rarely either one or
> the other but usually the interaction of the two that causes the problem
> or unexpected behavior.


Sure - which is why I want to move the complexity to just one place where I
can test it.
